node.title: How a Plea Deal in the Arbery Hate Crime Case Unraveled
node.alt: Ahmaud Arbery’s mother, Wanda Cooper-Jones, listens as Superior Court Judge Timothy Walmsley sentenced her son’s murderers last month in Brunswick, Ga. This week, she objected to a plea deal in the men’s hate crimes trial.
node.description: Prosecutors thought they had come up with an iron-clad deal to put Ahmaud Arbery’s killers away. But for his family, it wasn’t enough.
node.content: ["ATLANTA \u2014 Tara M. Lyons stood in a courtroom in Brunswick, Ga., this week with a dilemma no prosecutor wants.", "She had a deal with two of the murderers of Ahmaud Arbery, who had agreed to 30-year sentences on federal hate crime charges. But Mr. Arbery\u2019s family was firmly against it.", "\u201cI understand the anger, the pain and the struggle that the family is feeling with this resolution,\u201d Ms. Lyons told the court. \u201cI have no doubt if my son were chased down and shot like an animal because of the color of his skin, I would feel the same.\u201d", "But Ms. Lyons said that as a representative of the federal government, she had to leave her emotions at the door. She stood by the plea deal, which required the men to acknowledge that racism played a role in their actions when they chased Mr. Arbery down and shot him.", "U.S. District Judge Lisa Godbey Wood sided with the Arbery family and rejected the deal on Monday afternoon.", "Open dissent between prosecutors and victims is rare in a federal case as high-profile as the Arbery murder. And it is even rarer for a judge to side with the victims. In their fight to gain a greater voice in the United States criminal justice system over the past four decades, victims have won the right to be consulted on plea negotiations \u2014 but not to veto them.", "Joyce Vance, a former federal prosecutor whose father-in-law was murdered, said she understands when victims and prosecutors do not see eye to eye. She has never made peace with a plea deal that prosecutors made in her family\u2019s case. \u201cAll I wanted was my father-in-law back,\u201d she said. \u201cYou\u2019re not thinking as a victim about what the justice system can accomplish and what works the best.\u201d", "The role of victims in criminal prosecutions varies from state to state. Some require that they be informed in advance of any plea deal, others that they be consulted. Many states allow victims to speak or submit written statements to the court, and a few require prosecutors to inform judges of the victims\u2019 position on any proposed deal.", "In federal cases, victims have a \u201creasonable right to confer\u201d with prosecutors and the right to be informed of any deal. But prosecutors must weigh a host of other factors including the strength of their evidence, the interests of justice, and ensuring that similar crimes be met with similar punishments. A plea deal can ensure that a defendant will suffer some consequences, even if a victim views them as too lenient, while a trial may result in a full acquittal. And, prosecutors do not represent victims.", "\u201cIf you\u2019re a federal prosecutor, your client is the United States,\u201d said Michael J. Moore, an Atlanta lawyer who served as the U.S. attorney for middle Georgia from 2010 to 2015. \u201cThose lines, when you have a victim of a crime, can become blurry. There\u2019s the human side of you that\u2019s very empathetic to the victim\u2019s situation, and then there\u2019s maybe the more academic side and professional side, and professional obligation, that has to guide your conduct.\u201d", "Sometimes victims are on the side of mercy. When Dylann Roof killed nine members of a predominantly Black church in Charleston, S.C., federal prosecutors successfully sought the death penalty despite the church\u2019s opposition to capital punishment.", "In the Arbery case, Travis McMichael, 36, his father Gregory McMichael, 66, and a third man were charged with murder and convicted in state court. Federal prosecutors pursued other charges, including hate crime charges and attempted kidnapping. Georgia did not have a hate crime statute at the time of Arbery\u2019s death.", "Ms. Vance, the former prosecutor, said the deal that federal prosecutors struck in the Arbery case had been a good one. Hate crimes are difficult to prove at trial, she said. The deal ensured that the two men, Travis McMichael, 36, and his father, Gregory McMichael, 66, would serve significant time even if their convictions in state court were overturned on appeal, and it barred them from appealing the federal case. \u201cThat was a conviction that would stand for all time,\u201d she said.", "In court, the Arbery family objected to the deal at least in part because it would have allowed the McMichaels to serve time in federal prison, which is generally regarded as having better, safer conditions than state prisons. This may be especially true in Georgia, where last fall the Justice Department launched an investigation of state prisons, citing a high rate of murder and assault.", "\u201cI\u2019m asking on the behalf of his family, on behalf of his memory, and on behalf of fairness that you do not grant this plea in order to allow these men to transfer out of Georgia state custody into the federal prisons, where they prefer to be,\u201d said Wanda Cooper-Jones, Mr. Arbery\u2019s mother.", "Yet defense lawyers like MiAngel Cody, based in Chicago and Miami, question the assumption that the federal system, which was placed on lockdown this week after a gang fight in a high security unit in Texas, is an easier place to do time. \u201cPeople think that it\u2019s Club Fed,\u201d Ms. Cody said. \u201cTwo people were violently murdered in Club Fed yesterday.\u201d", "In a phone interview on Tuesday, Marcus Arbery Sr., Ahmaud Arbery\u2019s father, said he preferred for the men to face a jury of their peers for the federal charges.", "\u201cI\u2019d like to see them go forward on the evidence,\u201d he said.", "In the court hearing in Georgia on Monday, Ms. Lyons said that the Arbery family and its lawyers had been consulted numerous times by prosecutors about the possibility of a plea deal.", "In early January, a few days before the McMichaels were sentenced in state court, federal prosecutors took a proposed deal to the Arbery family, but eventually shelved it after listening to the family\u2019s concerns, Ms. Lyons said.", "But by Jan. 28, plea agreements had once again been hammered out between the McMichaels and prosecutors. Before those agreements were finalized, Ms. Lyons said, prosecutors consulted with lawyers for Ms. Cooper-Jones and Mr. Arbery\u2019s father, Marcus Arbery Sr. The family\u2019s lawyers told federal officials that the parents \u201cwould not oppose a plea agreement,\u201d Ms. Lyons said.", "But Ms. Lyons said that in a number of video meetings with family members and their lawyers on Sunday \u2014 the day before the hearing \u2014 it became apparent that the family was not in favor of the deal.", "\u201cI\u2019m not up here blaming the family, your honor,\u201d she said, adding that she had \u201cpersonally struggled\u201d over the right thing to do.", "Still, she said it was her job to make \u201csound decisions\u201d in the interest of justice. She asked the judge to accept the plea deal. Among other things, she argued that it would guarantee prison time for the McMichaels if the state convictions were thrown out on appeal, and noted that the men would admit that they were motivated by racial bias.", "Judge Wood did not explicitly say that she was rejecting the plea deal because of the family\u2019s objections, and experts said she may have had other reasons.", "In federal court, the vast majority of plea deals leave sentencing up to the judge. Prosecutors may agree to recommend a sentence on the lower end of the range prescribed by federal sentencing guidelines or agree to drop some charges, and a defendant may receive points in their favor for accepting responsibility for their actions. But the judge metes out the sentence.", "The deal presented in the Arbery case would have deprived the judge of that discretion. Judge Wood had to accept the deal as agreed, or reject it.", "Carissa Byrne Hessick, the author of \u201cPunishment Without Trial: Why Plea Bargaining is a Bad Deal,\u201d said judges should question plea deals more often. More than 97 percent of criminal convictions are resolved through plea deals, many of which are rubber-stamped by the courts, she said.", "\u201cThe fact that this is getting so much attention for the rejection of the plea deal \u2014 that just goes to show how much judges have abdicated their sentencing power,\u201d she said.", "Mr. Moore, the former federal prosecutor from Georgia, said that a number of families disagreed with plea agreements he had reached with defendants during his time in office. \u201cBut once you have some time to discuss it and explain it, most of the time families came around and understood,\u201d he said.", "He said he never had to deal with a situation like the one Ms. Lyons faced, in which a family objected to a plea deal in open court \u2014 and a judge sided with the family.", "The McMichaels are scheduled to appear before Judge Wood again Friday morning and tell her whether they want to plead guilty in the absence of a deal or declare themselves innocent and take their chances at trial.", "Jury selection will begin Monday in the trial, in which the McMichaels \u2014 if they decide to go forward \u2014 will defend themselves alongside William Bryan, 52, who, like the other men, was sentenced to life in prison by a Georgia judge for Mr. Arbery\u2019s murder.", "Some experts said that this week\u2019s hearing, which made clear that the McMichaels were willing to admit they had been motivated by racism, could make it difficult to choose an impartial jury.", "In the end, victims may struggle because the remedy they want most is outside the power of the courts to give, said Ms. Vance, the former prosecutor.", "\u201cNothing is going to bring Ahmaud back,\u201d she said."]
